Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading my brother’s message: “Don’t forget, we’re leaving for the family trip at noon. Mom’s counting on you to help with the kids.” My heart squeezed with guilt. I knew how much these holiday gatherings meant to everyone, especially after Dad’s health scare last year. But as I glanced at the pile of tools in my workshop, anxiety gnawed at me. The inspection forms were due today, and I hadn’t checked the saws or calibrated the levels yet. If I skipped the safety checks, I’d be risking not just my own fingers, but my crew’s as well. The foreman had been clear: “No shortcuts. One mistake, and someone could get hurt.” I could almost hear my mother’s voice, warm but expectant, asking me to be present, to be a good sister. At the same time, the weight of responsibility as a carpenter pressed on my shoulders. I stood frozen, torn between the laughter of my family waiting for me and the silent, urgent call of my unfinished workbench.
